results.title: Arctic people
results.brief_description: This film shows without commentary how hunting is the traditional means of livelihood for the Eskimos in the barren Canadian northland. It also indicates how the less hostile environment of the low Arctic permits the Lapps to engage in husbandry and fishing. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Arctic outpost
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and John Feeney
results.brief_description: Life at the small settlement of Pangnirtung on eastern Baffin Island, where there is as a Royal Canadian Mounted Police post, a Hudson’s Bay Company store, a mission hospital and a government school. The film presents on-the-spot accounts of the work of all of these. This is a shorter version of the film “Pangnirtung”.

results.title: Arctic nomads
results.brief_description: Life at the tiny outpost of Masi, on the edge of the vast Finnmark plateau over which the nomadic Lapps have wandered for centuries. Lapp children are shown at their lessons in a school built be the Norwegian State. Out on the plateau a family is shown living a primitive tent life, and preparing their sledges and reindeer to migrate to the coast in the spring. No other credits available.

results.title: Arctic jungle
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”.
The life of the Eskimo is a constant struggle for existence against the harshness of the Arctic environment. The film shows spear fishing, making lamp fuel, manufacturing clothing and kayaks, and hunting powerful quarry like the polar bear and white whale.

results.title: Arctic dog team
results.brief_description: A study of the training of husky dogs for their work in the Arctic and of the valuable part they play in the life of the Eskimos. Commentary by Doug Wilkinson. No other credits available.

results.title: Arctic adventure
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Dynamite Entertainment and Tim Bain
results.brief_description: When a bunch of autocratic bears move into the Arctic Circle the lives of its penguin population are instantly and dramatically changed as the region is transformed into a jail-like ‘zoo’. All attempts are being made to break loose whilst young love hangs in the balance and the wily Tek (Kim Gyngell) insists they can fly and escape. But it’s war for Sergeant Pepper (Rod Quantock) who declares “I like the smell of snowballs in the morning” and a battle of wits (or faith) ensues. Voices by: Sigrid Thornton, Eric Bana, Kim Gyngell, Linda Gibson, John Clarke, Rod Quantock, Tim Bain and Adrian Vaughan. Written and directed by Tim Bain.

results.title: Arctic 4
results.brief_description: A long film report of a new and daring step toward understanding what lies under the Arctic ice. This is the story of an Arctic diving expedition led by Dr. Joseph MacInnes and a team of scientists, during two months of continuous springtime daylight. The dives are a test of both men and equipment as well as an exploration of the high northern marine environment. What they discovered is interestingly documented in this film.

results.title: Arcs and sparks (Testing)
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Introduces the scientific idea that magnetism and electricity are related. Shows some safe ways to investigate that relationship. Suitable for Upper-Primary students.

results.title: Architype
results.creator_credit: Colin Thomas, Henry Lutman and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Animated Conversations”.
This brilliant short animation directed and animated by Henry Lutman uses a real conversation recording to portray two architects discussing a plan to build a new shopping mall. While the characters flick through large technical drafts of the mall a homeless man walks across the pages to reveal the social consequences of redevelopment and to show the viewer between the lines of the real conversation. The film outstandingly shows a multiplex of possible realities- the real conversation recording - the animated architects and a homeless man minimally draw into the stark architectural line drawings. The animated characters begin to seem more realistic than the real conversation recording the film is based on. This title is part of a series of animated films made by the BBC called Animated Conversations.

results.title: Architecture: a performing art
results.creator_credit: Michael Robertson Film Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: An overview of the career and lifestyle of the Australian architect, John Andrews whose better known accomplishments include the CTT Tower in Toronto - the tallest free-standing structure in the world, the International Shipping Terminal at Miami, the Cameron Offices in Canberra and the American Express Tower in Sydney.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Robertson Film Productions and Film Australia
